abstractText: A fragment of the Cāndravyākaraṇa of the Buddhist grammarian Candragomin with its most widespread and best known commentary, the Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti, for a long time believed to be the work of Candragomin himself, but now generally attributed to an author called Dharmadāsa , of which nothing else is known (Dash 1986; Oberlies 1989). In this manuscript each sūtra (i.e. rule) is separated from the commentary to the previous sūtra by a double daṇḍa followed by a small blank and another double daṇḍa, thus facilitating their identification despite the poor condition of the folios. The fragment contains a portion of the first section (pāda, literally “quarter”) of the fifth chapter (adhyāya), starting at some place before rule 5.1.16, śenṅitoḥ, which is legible, though barely, on f. 1r4, followed by rules 17, jyāvraścapracchabhrasjāṃ, f. 1r4; 18, vaśas tiṅśity apiti, f. 1r5; and 19, vyaco ñṇityasi, f. 1v6. The first rule identified by Bendall (1883: 159), namely 5.1.21, liṭy aśver dvirukte, appears on f. 1v1. In the rest of the manuscript the following sūtras are legible, more or less clearly: 23, svapaḥ, 1v4; 24, caṅi, 1v4; 25, yaṅi, 1v5; 26, vyesyamoḥ, 1v5; 27, cāyaḥ kīḥ, 1v5]; 28, pres styaś ca tatavatoḥ, 1v6; 29, sprśadravamūrtyoḥ śyaḥ, 1v6; 30, prateḥ, 1v7; 34, pyāyaḥ pīḥ, 2r3; 36, liḍyaṅoḥ, 2r5; 37, vā śveḥ, 2r5; 39, hvaḥ, 2v1; 40, dvitve, 2v2; 41, na tasmin, 2v3; 42, liṭi, 2v4; 43, vayo yaḥ, 2v5; 44, ver apiti vā, 2v6; 45, lyapi ca, 2v6; 46, jyaḥ, 3r1; 47, vyaḥ, 3r1; 48, parer vā, 3r2; 49, eco śity āt_, 3r2; 50, aliṭi¦ vyaḥ, 3r4-3r5; 51, sphurisphulor ghañi, 3r5; 52, dīṅo ’kṅitsan (!) lyapi, 3r6; 53, mimyor akhalaci, 3r7; 54, liyo vā, 3v1; 55, apaguro ṇamuli, 3v3; 56, [-1-]sphuror ṇau, 3v4; 57, prajane viyaḥ, 3v4; 58, bhiyaḥ prajojakāt_ (!), 3v5; 59, smeś ca, 3v6; 60, krīṅjīnā (!), 3v7; 61, aṣṭivuṣvaskādeḥ ṣas saḥ (!), 4r2; 62, ṇo naḥ, 4r4; 63, yo vali lopaḥ, 4r5; (sūtra 64, ver anacaḥ is omitted, certainly due to a scribal mistake, as the commentary on rule 63 is incomplete but, after a daṇḍa, the text continues with the final part of the commentary on sūtra 64); 65, halas tipsipaḥ, 4r6; 66, soḥ, 4r7; 67, ṅyāpo dirghāt, 4r7; 68, eṅ hrasvāt sambuddhāv ataḥ, 4r8; 69, hrasvasyātiṅi piti tuk, 4v2; 70, phe (!), 4v4; 71, āṅmāṅah, 4v4; 72, dīrghasya, 4r5; 73, padāntasya vā, 4v5; 74, iko yaṇ aci, 4v6; 75, [eco ’yavāyāvaḥ] , 4v7. The last legible sutra is 5.1.76, yi pare ’vāvau on f. 4v7. The rest of the chapter, which comprises 142 sūtras, is lost. The manuscript is badly damaged, but the readable portions correspond quite closely to the printed edition of the Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti (Chatterji 1965).
